feed.title: Nicholas M. Geyer
feed.subtitle: Website for Nicholas M Geyer of Colorado State University

entry.title: Progress on my Ph.D.
entry.content:
As time has quickly moved forward, I feel the need to update others on the progress of my Ph.D. For those of you that are interested here is the basic “checklist” of where my Ph.D. is at as of this date (roughly the middle of November 2021):

  • Re-enter graduate school
  • Take the Preliminary Exam
  • Complete Required Coursework
  • Complete Research for 1st paper
  • Complete Research for 2nd paper
  • Complete Research for 3rd paper
  • Complete 1st paper
  • Complete 2nd paper
  • Complete 3rd paper
  • Complete Dissertation (Draft)
  • Complete Pre-defense meeting
  • Complete Dissertation Defense

The progress is just a guess of what it should be. Although those bars may not show it, my progress is about halfway or so done. The course work and preliminary requirements are finished and I am in what I’d like to call the “research” phase. It is pretty much the time where a student more or less just focuses on research and writing. Since my re-entrance into graduate school (about 2.5 years ago), I have made significant progress in my research, but in 2020 and 2021 I hit a few large speed bumps along the way. Not just common things like the SARS-CoV-2 Pandemic, but also stuff like health and family.

As of today, I do not forsee these things being issues anymore. I am writing for more than an hour, reading a paper, and developing my Quick Studies for insertion into my Dissertation. These will continue to increase in the following weeks and I look forward to sharing my findings and future with you!

-N
entry.summary: As time has quickly moved forward, I feel the need to update others on the progress of my Ph.D. For those of you that are interested here is the basic “checklist” of where my Ph.D. is at as of this date (roughly the middle of November 2021):

entry.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
entry.content:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

Jekyll requires blog post files to be named according to the following format:

YEAR-MONTH-DAY-title.MARKUP

Where YEAR is a four-digit number, MONTH and DAY are both two-digit numbers, and MARKUP is the file extension representing the format used in the file. After that, include the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.
entry.summary: You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.
